samples.context: Children between the ages of 11 and 19 years are called adolescents. The onset of puberty brings about growth of the reproductive organs. Hair grow at various places on the body. Breasts develop in girls and facial hair (moustache and beard) appear in boys.
samples.question: What age group is referred to as adolescents?

samples.context: The onset of puberty and maturity of reproductive parts are controlled by hormones. Hormones are secretions of endocrine glands which pour them directly into the blood stream.
samples.question: What regulates the onset of puberty?

samples.context: Testosterone is the male hormone and estrogen, the female hormone. The uterine wall in females prepares itself to receive the developing fertilised egg.
samples.question: What are the primary male and female hormones?

samples.context: In case there is no fertilisation, the thickened lining of the uterine wall breaks down and goes out of the body along with blood. This is called menstruation.
samples.question: What happens if fertilisation does not occur?

samples.context: It is important to eat balanced food and maintain personal hygiene during adolescence. The pituitary gland secretes hormones which include growth hormone and hormones that make other glands secrete hormones.
samples.question: Why is nutrition important during adolescence?

samples.context: Breasts develop in girls and facial hair (moustache and beard) appear in boys. Voice of boys becomes hoarse as voice box enlarges during adolescence.
samples.question: What physical changes occur in boys during puberty?

samples.context: Pancreas secretes insulin, thyroid produces thyroxine and adrenals produce adrenalin. The sex of the unborn child depends on whether the zygote has XX or XY chromosomes.
samples.question: What determines the sex of an unborn child?

samples.context: Humans become capable of reproduction after puberty sets in. Children gain height during adolescence and the pituitary gland plays a key role in this.
samples.question: What happens to human reproduction after puberty?
